articles.headline: 5 Steps to Take if the Market Drop Has You Thinking of Unloading Stocks
articles.snippet: Wall Street’s decade-long surge raises a reasonable question for many people. Is it time to take some money off the table? Here’s a checklist to help you decide.
articles.abstract: Wall Street’s decade-long surge raises a reasonable question for many people. Is it time to take some money off the table? Here’s a checklist to help you decide.

articles.headline: Saudi Aramco Is Said to Postpone Its Potentially Record-Breaking I.P.O.
articles.snippet: The oil giant has put its plans for an initial public offering on hold, as it focuses on efforts to buy a stake in a Saudi chemical maker.
articles.abstract: The oil giant has put its plans for an initial public offering on hold, as it focuses on efforts to buy a stake in a Saudi chemical maker.
articles.lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabia’s state-owned oil giant has suspended its plans to go public, a decision that puts on hold what would have been by far the biggest initial offering on record — or perhaps signals its cancellation.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: Can Facebook, or Anybody, Solve the Internet’s Misinformation Problem?
articles.snippet: Facebook showed it was proactive against online threats when it revealed new global influence campaigns this week. But being proactive is far from finding a solution.
articles.abstract: Facebook showed it was proactive against online threats when it revealed new global influence campaigns this week. But being proactive is far from finding a solution.
articles.lead_paragraph: In theory, Facebook’s announcement on Tuesday that it had discovered and shut down a wide-ranging Iranian misinformation campaign should make you feel better.

articles.headline: When Is an Offense Impeachable? Look to the Framers for the Answer
articles.snippet: The constitutional convention in 1787 focused on corrupt conduct used to gain the presidency in drafting the impeachment clause.
articles.abstract: The constitutional convention in 1787 focused on corrupt conduct used to gain the presidency in drafting the impeachment clause.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — There are more serious crimes than violating campaign finance laws. Some offenders face jail time, while others catch a break.

articles.headline: Anatomy of a Crime: Sex, Hush Money and a Trump Fixer’s Guilty Plea
articles.snippet: Coordinating with Michael Cohen, a tabloid giant turned its tip line into a trip wire for negative stories that could hurt the Trump campaign, prosecutors said.
articles.abstract: Coordinating with Michael Cohen, a tabloid giant turned its tip line into a trip wire for negative stories that could hurt the Trump campaign, prosecutors said.
articles.lead_paragraph: The federal campaign finance and tax evasion case that is embroiling the White House began in the unlikeliest of places: the world of supermarket tabloids.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Rebecca R. Ruiz

articles.headline: As Trade War Intensifies, China Moves to Bolster Its Economy
articles.snippet: Weak growth puts Beijing at a disadvantage in dealing with the White House. But more spending and lending could worsen the country’s addiction to debt.
articles.abstract: Weak growth puts Beijing at a disadvantage in dealing with the White House. But more spending and lending could worsen the country’s addiction to debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — As China’s economy slows and the trade war with the United States intensifies, Beijing’s economic bosses are swinging into action.

articles.headline: How FireEye Helped Facebook Spot a Disinformation Campaign
articles.snippet: The cybersecurity company has shifted its attention to detecting disinformation and uncovering social media campaigns intended to influence politics.
articles.abstract: The cybersecurity company has shifted its attention to detecting disinformation and uncovering social media campaigns intended to influence politics.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — FireEye, a cybersecurity company that has been involved in a number of prominent investigations, including the 2016 attack on the Democratic National Committee, alerted Facebook in July that it had a problem.
articles.byline: By Kate Conger and Sheera Frenkel

articles.headline: Trump Denounces Justice Dept. as Investigations Swirl Around Him
articles.snippet: The president chiefly blamed Attorney General Jeff Sessions, complaining that he never “took control” of the Justice Department.
articles.abstract: The president chiefly blamed Attorney General Jeff Sessions, complaining that he never “took control” of the Justice Department.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump blamed the Justice Department on Thursday for the investigations surrounding him, criticized the deal struck with his former lawyer Michael D. Cohen and lashed out at Attorney General Jeff Sessions, who countered with a rare public rebuke of the president.
articles.byline: By Katie Benner, Nicholas Fandos and Katie Rogers

articles.headline: In ‘Small Fry,’ Steve Jobs Comes Across as a Jerk. His Daughter Forgives Him. Should We?
articles.snippet: Lisa Brennan-Jobs has written a memoir about her famous father. The details are damning, but she doesn’t want them to be.
articles.abstract: Lisa Brennan-Jobs has written a memoir about her famous father. The details are damning, but she doesn’t want them to be.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Steve Jobs told his daughter Lisa Brennan-Jobs that the Apple Lisa computer was not named after her, it was not a cruel lie to a little girl, she insists — he was teaching her “not to ride on his coattails.”

articles.headline: Betsy DeVos Eyes Federal Education Grants to Put Guns in Schools
articles.snippet: The Education Department is considering allowing states to tap a fund for educational overhaul and improvement to buy guns for educators, a use not approved by Congress.
articles.abstract: The Education Department is considering allowing states to tap a fund for educational overhaul and improvement to buy guns for educators, a use not approved by Congress.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Congress created its academic support fund three years ago, lawmakers had in mind a pot of money that would increase student access to art and music, mental health and technology programs at the nation’s most impoverished schools.
